pages.body:
Alternatives, complementary services and similar networks to [[ZeroNet]]

* [[MaidSafe]] - anonymous, encrypted, decentralised, safe, not yet released (paid)
* [[IPFS]] - decentralised file sharing (free)
* [[Storj]] - glorified decentralised storage (paid)
* [[SIA]] - yet another glorified decentralised storage (paid)
* [[Ethereum]] [[Swarm]] - smart contracts based distributed storage and distribution (paid)
* [[BigchainDB]] -

A network *plan to* offer anonymous, decentralised storage and platform based on blockchains. Based on yet another digital currency. You buy coins and use them to network.

MaidSafe is alpha-testing for years now, and there's no expected date to release anything stable. Positive reviewers usually spent money on MaidSafe coins and worry about their investment. Negative reviewers rather use [[ZeroNet]] and [[TOR]], or [[IPFS]].

A network *plan to* offer anonymous, decentralised storage and platform based on blockchains. Based on yet another digital currency. You buy coins and use them to network.

MaidSafe is alpha-testing for years now, and there's no expected date to release anything stable. Positive reviewers usually spent money on MaidSafe coins and worry about their investment. Negative reviewers rather use [[ZeroNet]] and [[TOR]].

[[Database]]
----
What is the database?
---
A database is a collection of information that is organized so that it can easily be accessed, managed, and updated. In one view, databases can be classified according to types of content: bibliographic, full-text, numeric, and images.

What is a database and what is it used for?
---
Sometimes referred to as database management systems (DBMS), database software tools are primarily used for storing, modifying, extracting, and searching for information within a database.

What is a database program?
---
A database program is the heart of a business information system and provides file creation, data entry, update, query and reporting functions. The traditional term for database software is "database management system" (see DBMS).

What's SQL?
---
It is the query language of the database. SQL make it possible to easily create connections, relations and filters on vast amouts of data, using statements like *"SELECT name, age, country FROM people JOIN countries ON (people.home=countries.name)"*.

The opposite of SQL-based RDBMS (*relational* database management systems, where there are relations, or connections defined between data elements) are the NoSQL databases, where the data usually looked up by a few simple keys, but the speed of the database is magnitudes faster than an RDBMS, and it's much easier to replicate or parallelise its use. 

[[ZeroNet]] uses SQLite, an SQL-based, fast, single-user RDBMS variant.

[[Database]]
----
What is the database?
---
A database is a collection of information that is organized so that it can easily be accessed, managed, and updated. In one view, databases can be classified according to types of content: bibliographic, full-text, numeric, and images.

What is a database and what is it used for?
---
Sometimes referred to as database management systems (DBMS), database software tools are primarily used for storing, modifying, extracting, and searching for information within a database.

What is a database program?
---
A database program is the heart of a business information system and provides file creation, data entry, update, query and reporting functions. The traditional term for database software is "database management system" (see DBMS).

What's SQL?
---
It is the query language of the database. SQL make it possible to easily create connections, relations and filters on vast amouts of data, using statements like "SELECT name, age, country FROM people JOIN countries ON (people.home=countries.name)".

The opposite of SQL-based RDBMS (*relational* database management systems, where there are relations, or connections defined between data elements) are the NoSQL databases, where the data usually looked up by a few simple keys, but the speed of the database is magnitudes faster than an RDBMS, and it's much easier to replicate or parallelise its use. 

[[ZeroNet]] uses SQLite, an SQL-based, fast, single-user RDBMS variant.

# ZeroNet

**ZeroNet** is a [[decentralized]] network of [[peer-to-peer]] users. It is built in [[Python]] and fully [[open source]], invented and created by [[nofish]]. Sites have specific addresses which can be accessed through a browser when using its client. ZeroNet is not [[anonymous]] by default, but users can hide their IP address by using the built in [[Tor]]-functionality. ZeroNet uses elliptic curve [[cryptography]] and the [[BitTorrent]] network.

Users can publish static or dynamic websites into ZeroNet and visitors automatically serve the visited website from their computer, with the option to stop serving the website at any time by either pausing or deleting it. Sites will remain online even if it is being served by only one [[peer-to-peer|peer]].

When changes are published by the site owner, connected [[nodes]] serving that site (previous visitors) will receive the updates done to the site's content.

ZeroNet comes with a built-in [[SQL]] [[database]]. This makes content-heavy site development easy. The [[database]] is also synced with hosting [[nodes]].

The existence of [[peer-to-peer]] online [[website]]s had been hypothesized for some time, with [[The Pirate Bay]] suggesting they would build such network, as well as [[BitTorrent Inc.]] which created the closed source [[Project Maelstrom]]. One other similar project is [[MaidSafe]], though it has not yet seen widespread use, and has been said to focus more on file storage.

**Hungary** is a weird European country. It's been great once, and they still busy remembering that. As of 2017 it's heading back to be a one party state dictatorship. 

Hungary have given the world plenty of intersting things, from ballpoint pens ("biros" for you zealanders) to H-bomb, from game theory to [[ZeroNet]]. And Rubik's cube. Soda water. Binoculars. Safety matches. Wolfram (tungsten for you out there) light bulbs. Carburetors. Helicopters. Electrical motors. Transformers. Electricity measurement. The assembly line concept. Phone exchange. Digital computing (at least the Neumann architecture, for those who groks the topic). Plasma TV. BASIC. Holography. Such things.

**Nofish** is the pseudonym used by the creator and main developer of [[ZeroNet]]. He's from [[Hungary]].

He is an evil being from a foreign plane bound to take over the world by destabilising governments, copyright enforcement institutions and surveillance agencies. One bit a time.

**Nofish** is the pseudonym used by the creator and main developer of [[ZeroNet]].

# ZeroWiki Issues

## Bugs
+ [FIXED] Posting multiple internal links consecutively results in odd effects. [[zite]] , [[wiki]] , [[wiki]] , [[zite]]
+ Don't work with special chars in page name (example - try to create page with _ char)
+ [FIXED] None of the icons visible on Win8.1 + Chrome
+ [FIXED] Opening ZeroWiki for the first time displays a huge number of messages "This page has been updated. Do you want to load the changes?"
+[FIXED] ËøôÊòØÈõ∂ÁΩëWIKI

Please report bugs in this section.

## Feature Requests
Please add feature requests here.
+ Page anchors
### Localization
* Localization for pages (example - we have [Help](?Help) page with default language (en) but if we add ?lang=$name you can get localized version)
*  interface localization 
* bifurcation of the localizated pages, each page for each language, being on it's own, separated from the ZeroWiki English. It could be like what it done for ZeroTalk, each ZeroTalk has it's own page in it's own proper language.
### Site management/moderation
* protected pages
* moderators
### Editing
* if 2 people editing page at the same time - show alert
    * or refuse to apply the changes if something changed in the meantime, and force the user to merge the two versions (git-like)
* Global 'recent changes' page
    * With follow button for zerohello
* highlight differences between versions when opening history (like Github)
    * or at least add a way to view/compare the differences between the different versions in the history.   
* upload content (images) but only as optional files
* [DONE] creative commons license for easier (legal) modification of articles
* anchor to elements (good for linking to citations)
* citations
* page anchors
* code element
* separate ZeroWiki: sites from normal sites
* [DONE] support [ [wikisite|alternative naming] ]
* Optional short user entered message for edits shown on the History page (edit summary)
* Talk page for each wiki page to keep discussions about edits off the articles
* More markdown elements support like quotes >, tables, etc
* Preview before saving page edits 
* MarkDown help menu (like the one zeroblog uses)
### Other
* .bit domain
* site search, with 'did you mean' style correction
* User pages
* Aggregate history page of all ZeroWiki page changes.

----

### To Link Is To Do

There's a problem with ZeroNet links because the host part http://host:port differs a lot from client to client and especially for proxies:

Try a link via 127.0.0.1:43110 using a proxy or with a different port number in your local setup... it'll fail...

* [Official zite](http://127.0.0.1:43110/search.kaffie.bit/) [üìé](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)

```
* [Official zite](http://127.0.0.1:43110/search.kaffie.bit/) [üìé](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)
```

Link without HOST part works with proxies too:

* [Official zite](/search.kaffie.bit/) [üìé](/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)

```
* [Official zite](/search.kaffie.bit/) [üìé](/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)
```

...seen something like that @ Himalaya...

...bye¬≤ from Alfie...

----

-> but there is afaik an addon, that makes urls like http://search.kaffie.bit usable ‚Ä¶ that would probably break it, not sure so. But agree, relative paths would be better.

----

Using 127.0.0.1-Links force you to use a local client.
Proxies soon will be a common entry point to ZeroNet.
Stripping http://host:port so kinda getting an absolute path relative to current host and port work best for me...

-- *yeti 20160314-1933-GMT*.

----

There definitely needs to be a standardized way of linking to ZeroNet sites. Relative linking works, but it indeed absolutely breaks the chrome extension. The other option is to simply build the URL depending on what the visitor's current URL is. It's not a simple 'a' tag and requires a bit of javascript magic, but certainly works. Kaffiene does something like this.

---

I'm not sure, but I think zeronet automatically replaces the host:port part. See the links on http://127.0.0.1:43110/main.0rc.bit , which are automatically translated to 0net://sitename.bit and then back to the correct url.

---

Maybe put `zero://<link>` instead of `http://<link>`, add a method to the Zero API to get the base (either `localhost:43110`, or any other). Let a JS script run on every page that translates `zero://` links to the good link ?

> *KindlyFire 13/06/16*

---

Kaffie found a ways to use `zero://` links. All is explained [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffie.bit/test.html?zp). What about using only this type of links ? It makes the parser really easier to write and make it configurable for each user, in its browser.

> *Emeraude 08/11/2016*

---

### Categories

We eventually will need a 'categories' box at the bottom of each page, where each category links to articles under that same category. Here are some possible categories: existing features (the follow button, optional files, cloning), planned features (merger sites, ipv6 support), specific sites, search engines, related projects (twister, i2p, tor, cjdns). Markdown's 'References' feature may be of use here.

---
### License

Why v3.0? Why not go for CC-BY_SA-4.0 which is internationalised? 

> *FlappyEarz 2017-12-14 10.30*
